item.title: Belfast XR Festival launches £200,000 fund to support emerging XR developers
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 21, 2026

2 Min Read

Image via Belfast XR Festival

Belfast XR Festival has launched a new £200,000 ($270,000) creative development fund to address what organizers describe as a "critical gap" in the UK's immersive media ecosystem. 

The UK-wide program has been dubbed 'Amplify: XR Labs' and will be delivered by Belfast XR Festival with support from BFI Creative Challenge Fund. 

Amplify: XR Labs will provide strategic early-stage support for new and emerging producers working on narrative-led XR and immersive projects. The intent is to de-risk early the earliest stages of development for creatives operating in the space by offering paid development time and tailored mentorship. 

The program is open to 10 teams based the UK—although they must be led by new and emerging producers and supporting by a director or writer and creative technologist. 

"Applicants may be new to XR, provided they can demonstrate emerging status within their existing screen or creative practice," reads an announcement. "Projects must be intended for development in a narrative immersive format using XR technologies, with the ambition to progress towards production, market readiness and distribution"

Amplify: XR Labs will support producers from backgrounds "historically under-represented in immersive media"

Successful applicants will receive a working stipend of £1,772.80 per team member (£5,318 per team); a three-day in-person residency in Belfast; bespoke masterclasses led by XR industry veterans; one-to-one project mentoring; five days of rapid prototyping and creative technology support per project; travel and accommodation costs; an accessibility stipend (including childcare support); and an invitation to an exclusive UK finance gap market and distribution event. 

Related:Exclusive: 1SP Agency acquires game event networking platform MeetToMatch

"Amplify:XR Labs has been intentionally designed to support producers from backgrounds and regions that have been historically under-represented in immersive media, with paid development time, covered travel and accommodation and dedicated accessibility support built into the programme," continues the announcement. 

"By removing practical and financial barriers to entry, Belfast XR Festival is working to ensure that the future of XR reflects a broader range of voices, lived experiences and creative leadership, which is essential if the sector is to grow in a fair, resilient and sustainable way."

Those interested can learn more about Amplify: XR Labs on the Belfast XR Festival website.

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.

item.title: Exclusive: 1SP Agency acquires game event networking platform MeetToMatch
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 21, 2026

2 Min Read

Video game marketing firm 1SP Agency has acquired B2B matchmaking and event platform MeetToMatch for an undisclosed fee.

MeetToMatch is used by over 60 international video game events to connect developers, publishers, investors, and other industry professionals through one-on-one meetings, networking sessions, workshops, and more. 

Those partners include upcoming events such as Pocket Gamer Connects, BitSummit, and Develop: Brighton.

Fedor van Herpen, co-founder of MeetToMatch, said the deal will enable the platform to scale faster, expand globally, and unlock new opportunities beyond the core video game industry.

"For event organizers, this means greater reach, deeper connections, and increased business impact. With strong backing for continued platform development, the partnership ensures a robust, future-proof solution designed to foster meaningful business relationships," said van Herpen. 

"Together, we now have the financial means and development power and are building a true Swiss Army knife for doing business across the games and digital entertainment industries, and we are looking forward to announcing the next phase of the MeetToMatch platform soon." 

MeetToMatch's new owners want to make game industry networking "faster, smarter, and more effective"

Related:Belfast XR Festival launches £200,000 fund to support emerging XR developers

Speaking to Game Developer about the deal, 1SP managing director Torsten Oppermann explained the company's near-term vision for MeetToMatch includes enhancing its core networking capabilities to create even more value for event organizers and users.

"We will accelerate feature releases that improve CRM capabilities across events, seamless scheduling, rich attendee profiles, and intuitive event navigation—ensuring users find relevant connections before, during and after each event," he added.

"MeetToMatch already helps participants schedule meaningful 1:1 meetings and fosters engagement through built-in messaging and meeting functionality; our plan is to build on these strengths to make networking faster, smarter, and more effective."

In the long-term, 1SP intends to transform MeetToMatch into a "global go-to platform" for professional matchmaking across in-person, virtual, and hybrid events. 

"This means continued investment in smarter recommendations, CRM and dealtracking features, deeper integrations with customer tech stacks, analytics dashboards for organizers, and event community features that extend engagement between event organizers and their delegates year-round," continued Oppermann. 

Notably, MeetToMatch co-founder and COO Ansgar Smith said the platform will remain just as committed to protecting user data under its new owners. 

Related:Netflix boss says cloud-based TV games are a 'big priority' in 2026

"MeetToMatch services—much like other networking platforms in this category—are designed with privacy and security by default, ensuring compliance with regulations such as GDPR for all user data," he added. 

"Rest assured that MeetToMatch is not selling private data and we are not risking leaking such data to public AI services. We maintain clear data governance policies at group level—including transparent terms of service and privacy notices—so users always understand how their data is handled and protected throughout their networking experience."

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.
